fields.name: HEROP_ID
fields.description: A derived unique id corresponding to the relevant geographic unit.
fields.comments: The HEROP_ID is generated as follows: Summary Level Code + "US" + GEOID + “-” + Year. In the case of ZCTA geographies, Summary Level Code is 860 and GEOID is the 5-digit Zip Code.

fields.name: TotPop
fields.description: Estimated total population in 2018
fields.source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 5-Year Estimates; 2010 Decennial Census; Integrated Public Use Microdata Series National Historic Geographic Information System
fields.comments: 1980, 1990, and 2000 data from respective decennial censuses downloaded from IPUMS NHGIS and crosswalked to 2010 census tracts using the Longitudinal Tract Database crosswalk files. They were then crosswalked to 2010 ZIPs using the 2012 1st quarter TRACT-ZIP crosswalk from Housing and Urban Development. For more on the tract crosswalk files, see https://s4.ad.brown.edu/Projects/Diversity/researcher/bridging.htm. For more on the TRACT-ZIP crosswalk, see https://www.huduser.gov/portal/datasets/usps_crosswalk.html

fields.name: TotPopHh
fields.description: Total number of people in households
fields.source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 5 Year Estimates

fields.name: TotVetPop
fields.description: Total veteran population
fields.source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 5-Year Estimates; American Community Survey 2008-2012 5-Year Estimates

fields.name: TotUnits

fields.name: BedCnt
fields.description: Number of beds available to homeless individuals in a continuum of care available at the time of the census
fields.constraints: This is the taken by a team of individuals in a continuum of care in one day. It is difficult to measure homelessness at a local and Federal level as the population is relatively mobile, homelessness can be cyclical and there are visibility issues for the homeless community, so the annual point in time count was used as a proxy for homelessness in this dataset. Data was geocoded then spatially joined at the tract, ZCTA, state and county level to see where continuums of care are located and the availibility of temporary housing solutions.
fields.source: Department of Housing and Urban Development Homeless Census, 2018

fields.name: PntInTm
fields.description: Number of housing-insecure individuals at a shelter on the day of the count
fields.constraints: This is the taken by a team of individuals in a continuum of care in one day. It is difficult to measure homelessness at a local and Federal level as the population is relatively mobile, homelessness can be cyclical and there are visibility issues for the homeless community, so the annual point in time count was used as a proxy for homelessness in this dataset. Data was geocoded then spatially joined at the tract, ZCTA, state and county level to see where continuums of care are located and the availibility of temporary housing solutions.
fields.source: Department of Housing and Urban Development Homeless Census, 2018

fields.name: YrlyBedCnt
fields.description: Number of beds available to homeless populations in group quarters available year-round
fields.constraints: This is the taken by a team of individuals in a continuum of care in one day. It is difficult to measure homelessness at a local and Federal level as the population is relatively mobile, homelessness can be cyclical and there are visibility issues for the homeless community, so the annual point in time count was used as a proxy for homelessness in this dataset. Data was geocoded then spatially joined at the tract, ZCTA, state and county level to see where continuums of care are located and the availibility of temporary housing solutions.
fields.source: Department of Housing and Urban Development Homeless Census, 2018

fields.name: AreaSqMi
fields.description: Land area of geography in sq miles
fields.constraints:
Alcohol outlet density is one approximation for accessibility or demand, though a limited one for describing or understanding the complex relationship between alcohol consumption and the surrounding area or communithy.

The category of 'alcohol outlets' included in this dataset does not include supermarkets and/or drug stores that may carry beer, wine, or liquor. The laws governing these sales varies from state to state, permitting alcohol sales in different kind of sales outlets. Outlets that are permitted to make these sales may not always fall under the same NAICS code for Beer, Wine, and Liquor Stores.
fields.source: InfoGroup's 2018 Business and Consumer Historical Datafile

fields.name: AlcTot
fields.description: Total number of alcohol outlets
fields.constraints:
Alcohol outlet density is one approximation for accessibility or demand, though a limited one for describing or understanding the complex relationship between alcohol consumption and the surrounding area or communithy.

The category of 'alcohol outlets' included in this dataset does not include supermarkets and/or drug stores that may carry beer, wine, or liquor. The laws governing these sales varies from state to state, permitting alcohol sales in different kind of sales outlets. Outlets that are permitted to make these sales may not always fall under the same NAICS code for Beer, Wine, and Liquor Stores.
fields.source: InfoGroup's 2018 Business and Consumer Historical Datafile

fields.name: AlcDens
fields.description: Number of alcohol outlets per square mile
fields.constraints:
Alcohol outlet density is one approximation for accessibility or demand, though a limited one for describing or understanding the complex relationship between alcohol consumption and the surrounding area or communithy.

The category of 'alcohol outlets' included in this dataset does not include supermarkets and/or drug stores that may carry beer, wine, or liquor. The laws governing these sales varies from state to state, permitting alcohol sales in different kind of sales outlets. Outlets that are permitted to make these sales may not always fall under the same NAICS code for Beer, Wine, and Liquor Stores.
fields.source: InfoGroup's 2018 Business and Consumer Historical Datafile

fields.name: AlcPerCap
fields.description: Number of alcohol outlets per capita
fields.constraints:
Alcohol outlet density is one approximation for accessibility or demand, though a limited one for describing or understanding the complex relationship between alcohol consumption and the surrounding area or communithy.

The category of 'alcohol outlets' included in this dataset does not include supermarkets and/or drug stores that may carry beer, wine, or liquor. The laws governing these sales varies from state to state, permitting alcohol sales in different kind of sales outlets. Outlets that are permitted to make these sales may not always fall under the same NAICS code for Beer, Wine, and Liquor Stores.
fields.source: InfoGroup's 2018 Business and Consumer Historical Datafile

fields.name: DsmBlk
fields.description: Dissimilarity index for Black and non-Hispanic White residents
fields.constraints: The three indices measuring residential segregation included here represent two categories of measures of residential segregation: measures of evenness (dissimiliarity) and measures of exposure (interaction and isolation). Three additional categories of residential segregation measurements described by Massey and Denton (1998) include measures of concentration, centralization, and clustering. Read more on the indices and their expressions from the U.S. Census Bureau.
fields.source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 5 Year Estimates
fields.comments:
From the U.S. Census Bureau, on Measures of Residential Segregation: "Massey and Denton (1988) used an extensive literature search and cluster analysis to identify 20 different indexes of segregation and classify them into five key dimensions of segregation. Basically, evenness involves the differential distribution of the subject population, exposure measures potential contact, concentration refers to the relative amount of physical space occupied, centralization indicates the degree to which a group is located near the center of an urban area, and clustering measures the degree to which minority group members live disproportionately in contiguous areas.""

Note: In all of the calculations, non-Hispanic whites are considered the "majority" (reference) population.

fields.name: Ndvi
fields.description: Average normalized difference vegetation index, a measure of greenness used to determine the amount of vegetation in an area, value from all pixel values in each Census tract
fields.constraints: Despite removing identified influences of cloud interferences, there may still be clouds or other atmospheric conditions that alter pixel values used in calculations. See the original source for greater documentation of these effects. Furthermore, summarizing NDVI to the census tract simplifies inter-census tract variability.
fields.source: Sentinel 2 MSI: MultiSpectral Instrument Level-1 C

fields.name: MoudMinDis
fields.description: Euclidean distance (miles) to nearest MOUD (all types)
fields.constraints: Access metrics are calculated for continental U.S., and does not include Hawaii, Alaska, or U.S. territories.
fields.source: U.S. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Treatment Locator, 2019; Vivitrol, 2020; Open Source Routing Machine, 200
fields.comments: All nearest distance calculations are in miles. All nearest travel time calculations are in minutes.

fields.name: FqhcMinDis
fields.description: Euclidean distance* from tract/zip centroid to nearest FQHC, in miles
fields.constraints: *Euclidean distance or straight-line distance is a simple approximation of distance or travel time from an origin centroid to the nearest health center. It is not a precise calculation of real travel times or distances.
fields.source: United States Covid Atlas via Health Resources and Services Adminsitration, 2020
fields.comments: This dataset includes all US states, Washington D.C., and Puerto Rico. It does not include the territories Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Palau. Zip code and tract centroids are not population-weighted.

fields.name: FqhcTmDr
fields.description: Driving time from tract/zip origin centroid to the nearest tract/zip FQHC destination centroid, in minutes
fields.constraints: *Euclidean distance or straight-line distance is a simple approximation of distance or travel time from an origin centroid to the nearest health center. It is not a precise calculation of real travel times or distances.
fields.source: United States Covid Atlas via Health Resources and Services Adminsitration, 2020
fields.comments: This dataset includes all US states, Washington D.C., and Puerto Rico. It does not include the territories Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Palau. Zip code and tract centroids are not population-weighted.

fields.source: United States Covid Atlas via Health Resources and Services Adminsitration, 2020
fields.comments: This dataset includes all US states, Washington D.C., and Puerto Rico. It does not include the territories Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Palau. Zip code and tract centroids are not population-weighted.

fields.comments: This dataset includes all US states, Washington D.C., and Puerto Rico. It does not include the territories Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Palau. Zip code and tract centroids are not population-weighted.
